awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Elements:Software:NSCI: Chrono - An Open-Source Simulation Platform for Computational Dynamics Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to augment modeling and solution methods employed by Chrono, an open-source computer simulation platform for multi-body dynamics (MBD) and fluid-solid interaction (FSI) problems. Chrono will be able to capture dynamics at various size and time scales spanning from millisecond (impact phenomena) to decades (geophysics). These performance levels open up new directions of research in several fields. Chrono is widely used and further developed by other users and has an active forum with more than 250 registered users currently. This project will enhance the richness of Chrono's modeling features, sound numerical solution foundation, and leverage of emerging hardware architectures to elevate this simulation capability to the status of ready-to-use, open-source, best-in-class computational dynamics platform. Chrono has been used by universities, national labs, and industry. Over the past two years, various groups have used Chrono in extraterrestrial applications, machine learning in robotics, image processing, pattern recognition and computer vision, mechanical watch design, architectural studies, autonomous vehicles, fluid-solid interaction applications, wind turbine dynamics, next generation space suit design, oil extraction and accident mitigation, hardware-in-the-loop simulation, etc. Finally, this project will engage high-school students from under-represented groups in a six-day residential camp run (now at its 12th edition) and will train a group of undergraduate students from California State University at University of Wisconsin-Madison through a new residential program that will introduce them to the use of Chrono in simulation-based robotics design.

This project seeks to augment modeling and solution methods employed by Chrono, a BSD3 open-source simulation platform for multi-body dynamics (MBD) and fluid-solid interaction (FSI) problems. The software infrastructure enhancements in this project aim at sustaining teraflops-grade simulation of MBD and FSI systems with more than ten billion degrees of freedom; i.e., two to three orders of magnitude beyond conventional simulations today. In order to increase adoption and impact, the performance levels aimed at will be reached on budget/affordable hardware that leverages GPU computing. Chrono will be able to capture micro-, meso- and macro-scale dynamics on time scales spanning from millisecond (impact phenomena) to decades (geophysics). The intellectual merit of this project stems from the following key ideas: (i) with an eye towards the sunsetting of Moore's law, the software design solution embraces a scalable multi-GPU hardware layout poised to solve effectively large multi-physics problems; (ii) a hardware-aware software design paradigm, which aggressively reduces data storage and movement, will allow budget-conscious hardware systems to run billion-degree-of-freedom models, or, for models of similar size, accomplish a two orders of magnitude speedup when compared to the state of the art; (iii) a unified Lagrangian formulation for both solid and fluid dynamics is implemented in one software platform that can simulate complex multi-physics (coupled) problems; and (iv) Chrono promotes an alternative approach for handling friction and contact that revolves around the concept of differential variational inequality and thus avoids the small integration time step and numerical instability issues that hinder most of the existing many-body dynamics simulators. In relation to its educational and outreach initiatives, this project: (a) will be instrumental in establishing a new University of Wisconsin-Madison undergraduate course that introduces students to computing concepts subsequently refined in a graduate advanced computing class; (b) will promote the discipline of Computational Science and Computational Dynamics at high-school and undergraduate levels via two yearly residential summer programs for under-represented students; (c) will expand an advanced computing forum that facilitates technology transfer to industry and promotes Chrono adoption; and, (d) will strengthen ongoing collaborations that critically depend on Chrono in robotics, geomechanics, and soft-matter physics. Chrono is presently cloned on average 10 times every day, has been forked from its public repository by more than 150 parties, and has an active forum with more than 250 registered users. This project will enhance the richness of Chrono modeling features, improve its numerical solution foundation, and leverage emerging hardware architectures to elevate this simulation capability to the status of ready-to-use, open-source, best-in-class computational dynamics platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was concerned with augmenting a physics-based simulation platform called Chrono with state-of-the-art solutions for granular dynamics and fluid-solid interaction problems. To that end, we have investigated modeling and numerical solution techniques and integrated some of them in an open source, freely available simulation platform that is used for computer aided engineering tasks. The compute acceleration platforms targeted for use by Chrono include GPU computing (via CUDA), multi-core parallel computing (via OpenMP), and distributed memory parallel computing (via MPI).

 

Our major accomplishments are as follows:

* We produced a GPU simulator for granular dynamics problems using the Discrete Element Method (DEM). The solution can tackle billion degree of freedom systems.

* We improved our Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) solver so that the Chrono simulation platform can tackle, with the same solver, both fluid dynamics and terramechanics problems

* We made Chrono more user friendly - we presently have more than 600 Chrono user-forum members, a doubling of the number of members over the lifespan of this project.

 

At the end of April 2023, we released version 8.0 of the Chrono simulation platform. The code is hosted on GitHub, it is open source, released under a BSD3 license for unfettered inspection, modification, repackaging, and distribution. The simulator has approximately 0.5 million lines of (mostly) C++ code.

 

Relevant links:

- Project Chrono website: http://www.projectchrono.org/

- Chrono GitHub website: https://github.com/projectchrono/chrono

- Chrono projects repo: https://github.com/projectchrono/chrono-projects

- Python wrapper: https://anaconda.org/projectchrono/pychrono

 

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this project was anchored by the following key ideas: (i) with an eye towards the sunsetting of Moore's law, the software design solution we adopted embraced a scalable GPU hardware layout that allowed us to solve effectively large multi-physics problems; (ii) we embraced a hardware-aware software design paradigm, which aggressively reduces data storage and movement thus allowing budget-conscious hardware systems to run billion-degree-of-freedom models, or, for models of similar size, accomplish a two orders of magnitude speedup when compared to the state of the art; (iii) we established a unified Lagrangian formulation for both solid and fluid dynamics and implemented it in one software platform that can simulate complex multi-physics (coupled) problems; and (iv) we promoted an alternative approach for handling friction and contact that revolved around the concept of differential variational inequality and which avoided the small integration time step and numerical instability issues that hinder most of the existing many-body dynamics simulators.

 

Broader impact: At a time when the scientific community runs granular dynamics simulations with approximately 10,000-100,000 elements, to the best of our knowledge, the largest Discrete Element Method simulation of practical relevance to date had 2.4 billion elements. It was run on 16,384 CPUs (131,072 cores) of Japan's K-supercomputer, the 2012 fastest supercomputer in the world. The most significant result in this project is that we ran simulations with more than 200 million elements with friction, and 700 million elements, without friction, on *one* NVIDA GPU card. We have released this code in a new Chrono module called Chrono::GPU, which does both granular dynamics and fluid dynamics simulation on the GPU.

 

The broader impact dimension of this project is also associated with the following accomplishments:

- Our software has been adopted and used by NASA for their 2024 VIPER mission, and for the ARTEMIS lunar mission.

- Our simulator has been embedded by the US Army in their Mercury simulation infrastructure used to design and test military vehicles operating in off-road conditions.

- We organized during the lifespan of this project three Machine-Ground Interaction Consortium, which drew more than 300 participants. For details, see https://sbel.wisc.edu/magic/.

- We organized three high-school residential programs (ProCSI-H, from high-school), which engaged more than 60 high-school students from several states. These camps were free, and they assumed the form of a summer residential program on the campus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison that introduced the participants to various research areas that are enabled by the use of computers. For details, see https://sbel.wisc.edu/procsi/.

- In collaboration with colleagues from California State University at Los Angeles (CSULA), we organized the ProCSI-C residential program on the campus of UW-Madison. CSULA is a minority-service institution in metropolitan Los Angeles; it offers no PhD degrees. This ProCSI-C program is an outcome of this very NSF project, which allowed colleagues from UW-Madison and CSULA to spend two weeks together working on the topics of simulation in robotics. In 2022, the CSULA students brought over their robot and, with UW-Madison student support, engaged in development and testing activities at UW-Madison. For details, see https://sbel.wisc.edu/procsi/.
